slides.mascot_explanation: This step is about mathematical magic tricks, and here's the cool part: they're not really magic! They work because of clever math hidden behind the scenes. Understanding why they work helps us see how amazing and surprising math can be.

slides.prompt: Complete at least three mathematical challenges: (1) Solve a logic puzzle (Sudoku or KenKen). (2) Play a strategy game and explain the mathematical thinking behind your winning strategy. (3) Learn and perform a mathematical magic trick, then explain the math that makes it work. Bonus: Create an original mathematical puzzle or game and test it with a partner.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to dive in and do some math fun! You need to pick at least three challenges: solve a logic puzzle like Sudoku, play a strategy game and tell me how you won using math ideas, and then learn a magic trick and explain the math behind it. If you have extra time, try making your own puzzle!

slides.text: Mathematics at its best is not drudgery — it is discovery, play, and the thrill of figuring something out. Carry this joy with you. Whenever math feels hard in the future, remember: the struggle is part of the play, and the solution is the reward.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student solve logic puzzles using systematic reasoning, explain mathematical strategies in games, understand the math behind a magic trick, and experience math as enjoyable?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're wrapping up our math playdate, and this slide is reminding us that math isn't just about hard work; it's also about the thrill of solving things and discovering new ideas. Remember this feeling of fun and accomplishment, and know that even when math gets tricky, figuring it out is the best reward.

parent_notes: This lesson is deliberately fun — and that is the point. Developing a positive relationship with mathematics is as important as learning specific skills. If your child enjoys these activities, keep puzzle books, strategy games, and math apps available over the summer. Games like Set, Blokus, and Mastermind develop mathematical thinking without feeling like 'school.' The mathematical magic tricks are great for building confidence — your child can perform them for friends and family, making math 'cool.'

title: Living History Presentation — Becoming a Historical Figure
description: Students research and prepare a living history presentation, embodying a historical figure studied this year. They write a first-person monologue, create a simple costume element, and perform as their chosen figure for an audience.
instructions:
1. Choose a historical figure studied this year that the student finds fascinating.
2. Research the figure's life, accomplishments, challenges, and personality.
3. Write a first-person monologue (2-3 minutes) in the character's voice.
4. Include: who they are, what they accomplished, what challenges they faced, and why their work matters.
5. Create a simple costume element or prop that identifies the character.
6. Practice performing the monologue in character: voice, posture, mannerisms.
7. Prepare to answer questions in character after the performance.
8. Perform the living history presentation.
9. After performing, step out of character and discuss what was learned.
10. Reflect on how performing as someone else deepens understanding.

slides.heading: Living History Presentation
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just the title page, letting you know that you're about to start a really cool project where you get to become someone from history for a little while. It's all about bringing the past to life by stepping into the shoes of a historical figure.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather research materials on the chosen historical figure. Collect or create simple costume elements. Set up the performance space. Have the camera ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists everything you'll need for this project, kind of like a treasure map for your presentation. You'll need your research notes to know all about your person, paper and a pen to write your speech, some simple costume pieces to look the part, a clear space to practice and perform, and maybe some reference books or websites.

slides.text: Living history presentations bring the past to life by letting you speak AS a historical figure. Choose someone whose story fascinates you — someone you feel you can understand and portray with respect and accuracy.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about picking your historical hero! Think about all the people we've learned about this year – who really sparked your interest or made you think, "Wow, I want to know more about them"? Choose someone you feel a connection to, because that'll make your presentation way more fun.

slides.text: Write your monologue in first person: 'I am [name] and I [did something remarkable].' Include personal details that make the figure human: their fears, their hopes, the obstacles they overcame. History is about people, not just events.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now you get to write what your historical figure will say, and the coolest part is you're writing it as if *you* are them! Start with "I am..." and then share what amazing things they did, but also talk about their worries or the tough times they went through, because that's what makes history feel real and relatable.

slides.text: A simple costume element makes your presentation memorable: a hat, a shawl, a badge, or even a prop (a telescope for Galileo, a notebook for Darwin). You do not need an elaborate costume — one recognizable element is enough.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you add a little visual magic – think of it as a secret handshake that tells everyone who you're pretending to be. It doesn't need to be a full costume; maybe just a special hat, a cool scarf, or something they always carried, like a scientist's notebook or an explorer's map.

slides.text: Performing in character means committing fully. Use a voice that feels appropriate. Stand and move as the character might have. If someone asks a question, answer as the character would. The more you commit, the more powerful the experience.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about acting! Once you know what you're going to say, you need to *become* that person. Try talking in a voice they might have used, stand up tall like they would have, and if someone asks you a question, answer it as if you're still that historical figure.

slides.prompt: Prepare and perform your living history presentation: (1) Research your chosen figure thoroughly. (2) Write a 2-3 minute first-person monologue. (3) Create or assemble a simple costume element. (4) Practice performing in character. (5) Perform for the audience and answer at least 2 questions in character. (6) Step out of character and share one thing you learned about this person that surprised you.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is the big moment where you get to shine! You'll pull together everything you've done – your research, your speech, your costume – and perform it. After you've shown everyone who you are, you'll step out of character to share something new you learned, and then we'll see how much you've mastered the project.

slides.text: When you speak as someone from history, you understand them in a way that reading about them cannot achieve. You feel their courage, their frustration, their hope. That empathy across time is what makes history truly meaningful.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student research a historical figure accurately, write and perform a first-person monologue, maintain character during questions, and articulate what they learned through the experience?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide wraps it all up by talking about why this project is so awesome. When you actually pretend to be someone from history, you start to understand them on a deeper level, like you can feel what they felt. That connection, that feeling of understanding someone from a totally different time, is what makes history super meaningful and powerful.

parent_notes: Living history presentations are engaging and memorable. Help your child research their figure and create a simple costume element, but let them write the monologue independently. Being the audience is important — ask genuine questions in character (address the figure by name). This performance builds on the public speaking skills practiced earlier this week. Record the presentation as a keepsake. If your child is reluctant to perform alone, offer to do a living history presentation alongside them — modeling vulnerability encourages it.

title: Global Citizenship — My Place in the World
description: Students explore the concept of global citizenship, examining how they are connected to people and places around the world through trade, communication, environment, and shared humanity. They create a personal 'My Place in the World' reflection showing their connections.
instructions:
1. Define global citizenship: being aware of and caring about the wider world while acting locally.
2. Map personal connections to the global community: products you use, foods you eat, music you listen to, people you communicate with.
3. Discuss shared global challenges: climate change, poverty, access to education, public health.
4. Examine the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals — which ones resonate?
5. Discuss how local actions create global impact (and vice versa).
6. Create a 'My Place in the World' map showing concentric circles: me, family, community, country, world.
7. Draw connections between each level.
8. Identify one global issue you care about and one local action you can take.
9. Write a 'Global Citizen Statement' — your commitment to the wider world.
10. Discuss what it means to be both local and global at the same time.

slides.heading: Global Citizenship
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing our topic: "Global Citizenship." It's basically about realizing that even though we live in our own town or neighborhood, we're all connected to people and places all over the whole world. Think of it like being part of a giant team!

slides.setup_instructions: Display the world map and globe. Print the concentric circle template. Have the UN Sustainable Development Goals poster or printout accessible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we need to gather our supplies for our big project. We've got a world map and a globe to help us see where places are, a special template for drawing circles, some colored pencils and paper for drawing and writing, and a poster about the UN Goals, which are like world-wide missions. Make sure you have all these things ready to go, maybe ask a grown-up to help you find them.

slides.text: You are a citizen of your town, your state, your country — and the world. Global citizenship means understanding that your actions affect people you will never meet, and their actions affect you. We are all connected.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step is all about understanding that you're not just a citizen of your town or country, but of the entire world too. It means knowing that what you do, like recycling or helping a neighbor, can actually make a difference to people far away, and their lives can impact yours too, even if you never meet them. We're all in this together!

slides.text: Look at the label on your shirt, the origin of your breakfast, the technology in your hand. Your daily life is global. Understanding these connections makes you a more informed, more compassionate, more effective citizen.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is showing us how our everyday lives are already connected to the rest of the world. Think about the clothes you're wearing – where were they made? Or the food you ate for breakfast – did it come from another country? Even the phone or tablet you might be using connects you to people and ideas globally, so your daily routine is actually pretty international!

slides.text: The United Nations created 17 Sustainable Development Goals for the world to achieve by 2030: ending poverty, quality education for all, clean water, climate action, and more. Which of these goals matters most to you? Why?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look at some really important goals that people all over the world are trying to achieve, like making sure everyone has enough to eat, getting a good education, or protecting our planet. These are called the Sustainable Development Goals. Think about which one of these big goals feels most important to you and why you care about it.

slides.text: Think local, act global. Think global, act local. Both are true. Cleaning up a local river helps the global ocean. Reducing your carbon footprint helps the global climate. Your actions ripple outward.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step talks about how our actions, big or small, can have effects far beyond where we live. For example, if you help clean up a park in your town, that's good for your local environment, but it also helps the bigger picture of keeping our planet healthy. It's like throwing a pebble in a pond – the ripples spread out really far!

slides.prompt: Create your 'My Place in the World' project: (1) Draw concentric circles showing you at the center, then family, community, country, and world. (2) Map your connections at each level. (3) Select one UN Sustainable Development Goal that matters to you. (4) Identify one local action you can take that connects to that global goal. (5) Write a Global Citizen Statement: who you are, what you care about, and how you will contribute to the wider world.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be creative and build your "My Place in the World" project! You'll draw circles starting with yourself in the middle, then family, your community, your country, and the whole world. Then, you'll draw lines showing how you're connected at each level, pick a UN goal you care about, figure out one small thing you can do locally to help with it, and finally, write a short statement about what kind of global citizen you want to be.

slides.text: You are part of a human family of 8 billion people sharing one planet. The geographic knowledge you have built this year — understanding regions, cultures, economies, and environments — makes you a more informed global citizen. Use that knowledge wisely.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain global citizenship, map personal connections to the world, identify a UN Sustainable Development Goal they care about, and write a meaningful Global Citizen Statement?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is reminding us that you're part of a huge global family, and all the cool stuff you've learned about different places and cultures this year helps you be a better global citizen. It's about using your knowledge to understand the world better and make positive choices, knowing that your actions matter, no matter how small they seem.

parent_notes: Global citizenship education is a Montessori hallmark. This lesson connects all the geographic, historical, and scientific knowledge from the year into a personal framework. The concentric circles visualization helps children see themselves as part of increasingly larger communities. The UN Sustainable Development Goals give structure to global awareness. The Global Citizen Statement is a powerful document that captures your child's emerging worldview and values. Display it alongside their personal precept from the Wonder reading.

title: The Wild Robot — Chapters 1-20: Roz Discovers Her World
description: Students begin reading 'The Wild Robot' by Peter Brown, exploring themes of nature, technology, adaptation, and belonging as a robot named Roz wakes up on a wilderness island and must learn to survive among wild animals. They analyze how Roz's journey reflects universal themes of identity and community.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and author. Peter Brown created both the text and illustrations.
2. Read chapters 1-20 aloud, pausing for discussion and to examine illustrations.
3. Discuss the premise: How does a robot end up on an island? What makes this science fiction?
4. Analyze how Roz learns about her environment: observation, trial and error, adaptation.
5. Compare Roz's learning process to the scientific method.
6. Discuss how the animals react to Roz: fear, curiosity, hostility. Why?
7. Examine the theme of 'outsider' — how is Roz's experience similar to August's in Wonder?
8. Discuss the nature vs. technology tension in the story.
9. Vocabulary: camouflage, adaptation, wilderness, solitude, observation.
10. Students predict how Roz will find her place on the island.
materials_needed: The Wild Robot by Peter Brown

slides.heading: The Wild Robot
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing us to the book we're going to read, "The Wild Robot," and the part we're focusing on, which is about when the robot, Roz, first wakes up and starts figuring out the island she's on. It's like the title screen for our adventure!

items: The Wild Robot by Peter Brown
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Prepare a character tracking chart adapted for animal characters. Start a vocabulary list of nature and technology terms.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide lists all the stuff we'll need for our reading journey. We've got the book itself, a reading journal to write down our thoughts, a character chart to keep track of who's who (especially the animals!), a vocabulary list for new words, and some paper for drawing. Make sure you have all these ready to go so we can dive right in!

slides.text: Peter Brown's 'The Wild Robot' asks a beautiful question: What happens when technology meets nature? Roz is a robot with no memory of how she arrived on a wild island. Everything she encounters is new, and she must learn to survive from scratch.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is setting the stage for our story. It's telling us that the book is about what happens when something totally man-made, like a robot, ends up in the middle of nature. Our robot, Roz, has no idea how she got there, so she has to learn everything about the island all by herself.

slides.text: Watch how Roz LEARNS. She observes. She experiments. She fails. She adapts. Her learning process mirrors the scientific method — and it mirrors how every living creature on the island learned to survive. Technology and nature use the same approach.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is super important because it explains *how* Roz learns. She watches everything, tries things out (even if they don't work at first!), and then changes how she does things. This is actually just like the scientific method scientists use, and it's how all animals learn to survive too – a cool connection between technology and nature.

slides.text: The animals fear Roz because she is different. They call her a monster. Think about August in Wonder — he was also feared for being different. What do these stories tell us about how we treat those who are not like us?
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're thinking about how the animals react to Roz. They're scared of her because she's so different, kind of like how some kids in the book *Wonder* were scared of August because he looked different. This slide wants us to think about why people (or animals!) get scared of things they don't understand and what that tells us about fitting in.

slides.text: Notice Peter Brown's illustrations. He created every image in this book. The contrast between Roz's angular, mechanical form and the organic curves of nature tells a visual story alongside the written one.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide points out how the author, Peter Brown, also drew all the pictures. Look closely at them – you can see how Roz looks sharp and mechanical, while everything else is soft and natural. The pictures are telling their own story about the robot in the wild, right alongside the words.

slides.prompt: Write a reading journal entry comparing Roz's experience as an outsider on the island with August's experience as an outsider at school. How are their challenges similar? How are they different? What strategies does each use to find acceptance? Then predict: How do you think Roz will find her place in this community of wild animals?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to do some writing! In your journal, compare how Roz feels like an outsider on the island to how August felt at school. Think about what's similar and different in their struggles, and how they try to make friends. Then, use your imagination to predict how you think Roz will eventually find her place among all the wild animals.

slides.text: Roz is learning what every newcomer must learn: how to observe, how to adapt, how to contribute, and how to belong. Her journey as a robot among animals is a metaphor for anyone who has ever felt like they do not fit in — and found a way to belong anyway.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student analyze Roz's learning and adaptation process, compare themes across novels, discuss the nature/technology tension, and make thoughtful predictions?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the wrap-up, reminding us that Roz's story is about more than just a robot. It's about learning to fit in, no matter how different you seem. She has to learn how to watch, change, help out, and belong, which is something everyone experiences when they're new somewhere. You did a great job exploring all these ideas!

parent_notes: The Wild Robot is a gentle, beautiful book that works on multiple levels. Young readers enjoy the adventure; older readers appreciate the philosophical questions about nature, technology, and what it means to belong. The connection to Wonder extends the empathy work from the previous book. If your child enjoyed the nature journal work, they will appreciate how Brown celebrates the natural world. Read along if you can — this is a book that sparks wonderful family discussions about technology's role in our lives.

title: Vocabulary Celebration — Words You Have Made Your Own
description: Students celebrate their vocabulary growth by reviewing words learned throughout the year, playing vocabulary games, and creating a personal lexicon of favorite words. They reflect on how an expanded vocabulary has improved their reading, writing, and thinking.
instructions:
1. Count the total number of vocabulary words learned this year.
2. Review vocabulary notebooks and identify words that have become part of active vocabulary.
3. Play vocabulary games: Vocabulary Charades, Word Association, Synonym Challenges.
4. Discuss how vocabulary connects to reading comprehension — more words means more understanding.
5. Identify 'power words' — vocabulary words that changed how you think or express yourself.
6. Create a personal lexicon: a booklet of favorite words with definitions, origins, and example sentences.
7. Play a 'Use It in a Sentence' challenge with advanced vocabulary.
8. Discuss strategies for continuing to build vocabulary: reading widely, looking up unfamiliar words, word-a-day habits.
9. Write a paragraph using at least 10 vocabulary words learned this year.
10. Reflect: How has having more words changed the way you think?

slides.heading: Vocabulary Celebration
slides.subheading: Words You Have Made Your Own
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our fun vocabulary party! It's called "Vocabulary Celebration" and it means we're going to look back at all the awesome new words we learned this whole year and celebrate how much smarter our brains have gotten. Think of it as a party to show off how many words you've collected and really learned how to use!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all vocabulary notebooks. Prepare game materials. Create blank booklets for the personal lexicon (fold and staple paper). Have the dictionary available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is showing us all the stuff we'll need for our vocabulary celebration. We've got our vocabulary notebooks where we wrote everything down, some materials for games (like maybe some cards or something fun!), and blank booklets we'll make into our own special word dictionaries. We also need colored pencils to make them pretty, a real dictionary for checking words, and some paper for writing. Go grab all these things with a grown-up's help so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Words are tools for thinking. The more words you know, the more precisely you can think and communicate. This year you added hundreds of words to your vocabulary. Today we celebrate that growth.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that words are like superpowers for our brains! The more words we know, the better we can think about things and explain them to other people. We've learned a *ton* of words this year, and this is our chance to see how many cool tools we've added to our thinking toolbox. It's pretty amazing how much our vocabulary has grown, right?

slides.text: There is a difference between words you RECOGNIZE and words you USE. Look through your vocabulary notebook. Which words have become part of your natural speech and writing? Those are the words you truly OWN.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this slide is about figuring out which words you *really* know, not just the ones you've seen before. It's like the difference between recognizing a face in a crowd and actually knowing that person's name and having a conversation with them. Take a look through your notebook and think about the words that pop into your head when you're writing or talking – those are the ones you truly *own*.

slides.text: Some words change how you think. Learning the word 'empathy' gives you a concept that 'feeling sorry for someone' does not quite capture. Learning 'perspective' lets you name the idea of seeing through someone else's eyes. These are POWER WORDS.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super cool idea – some words are like "power words" because they actually change how you think or help you understand things in a totally new way. For example, knowing the word "empathy" helps you understand a deeper feeling than just feeling sorry for someone. These special words give you new ideas and ways to explain the world.

slides.text: The best way to keep building vocabulary is to keep reading. Readers encounter new words in context, which is the most natural and effective way to learn them. Every book is a vocabulary lesson in disguise.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide reminds us that the best way to keep getting smarter with words is to keep reading! When you read, you see words used in sentences, which helps you understand exactly what they mean and how to use them yourself. Think of every book you read as a secret lesson where you're picking up awesome new vocabulary without even trying.

slides.prompt: Create your personal lexicon booklet with your 15-20 favorite vocabulary words from the year. For each word, include: the definition, the word's origin if interesting, an example sentence you wrote, and why you chose it. Then write a paragraph using at least 10 vocabulary words from the year, demonstrating that you truly own them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to get creative! You're going to make your own special booklet, like a mini-dictionary of your favorite words from this year. Pick about 15 to 20 words you really like, write down what they mean, maybe where they came from, and then write your *own* sentence using each word. After that, you'll write a paragraph using at least 10 of your vocabulary words, showing off how well you know them!

slides.text: Language is power. Every word you learn gives you a new tool for understanding the world and expressing yourself. Your vocabulary growth this year is invisible but immense — it lives in every book you read more deeply, every essay you write more precisely, and every conversation you navigate more skillfully.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify words that have become part of their active vocabulary, create a personal lexicon with definitions and examples, and demonstrate vocabulary use in context?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is celebrating how awesome you are with words! Every single word you learn is like getting a new tool to understand the world better and share your own ideas more clearly. Your vocabulary has grown so much this year, and that means you can read more deeply, write more clearly, and understand conversations even better. You've totally rocked this vocabulary journey!

parent_notes: Vocabulary growth is one of the most impactful but hardest-to-see aspects of literacy development. The personal lexicon booklet makes this growth tangible. Playing vocabulary games as a family is genuinely fun and reinforces learning. Encourage a 'word of the week' habit over the summer — your child can choose a new word each week and try to use it in conversation. Model vocabulary building yourself by sharing interesting words you encounter. Reading aloud together, even at this age, exposes children to vocabulary beyond their independent reading level.

title: Mathematical Reflection — Writing Your Math Story
description: Students write a comprehensive mathematical reflection examining their growth, challenges, breakthroughs, and goals. They articulate what they have learned about themselves as mathematical thinkers and how their relationship with math has evolved over the year.
instructions:
1. Review the math portfolio and all mathematical work from the year.
2. Identify the three most significant mathematical achievements.
3. Identify the biggest mathematical challenge and how it was overcome (or is still being addressed).
4. Write about a specific 'breakthrough moment' — when a concept suddenly clicked.
5. Describe your problem-solving style: What strategies come naturally? What strategies did you learn?
6. Discuss mathematical confidence: How has it changed over the year?
7. Write a comprehensive math reflection (2-3 paragraphs).
8. Include advice to a future student: 'What I wish I had known about math at the beginning of the year.'
9. Set specific, measurable math goals for next year.
10. Add the reflection to the math portfolio.
materials_needed: Math work samples from the year

slides.heading: Mathematical Reflection
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a book, and your book is all about *your* math journey this year. It’s called "Mathematical Reflection," which means you're going to think back on everything you've done in math, kind of like telling your own personal math story.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the math portfolio accessible. Print reflection prompts and goal-setting template. Set up a quiet workspace for thoughtful writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is showing us the tools we'll need for our math story. We have your math portfolio, which is like a scrapbook of all your work. Then there's writing paper for writing, math samples to look back on, a goal-setting sheet to help plan for the future, and some prompts to get your thinking started. You'll want to gather all these things, maybe with a grown-up's help, and find a quiet spot to focus.

slides.text: Every mathematician has a story — moments of frustration, breakthroughs of understanding, and the satisfaction of solving something hard. Your mathematical story this year is unique and worth telling.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that everyone's math experience is different, like a story with ups and downs. You've had moments where things were tough, times when something suddenly made sense, and times when you felt really proud of figuring something out. Your math story this year is totally yours, and it's important to share it.

slides.text: Think about your biggest BREAKTHROUGH moment. Maybe it was when fractions suddenly made sense, or when you solved your first equation, or when you realized that math is not about being fast but about thinking deeply. That moment matters.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to think about the "aha!" moments – those times when a math idea just clicked, like a lightbulb turning on. Maybe it was finally understanding how to add fractions or solving a tricky word problem. This slide reminds us that these breakthrough moments are super important parts of your math story.

slides.text: Be honest about challenges too. Every mathematician hits walls. The difference between those who grow and those who give up is persistence. If you are still working on something, that is not failure — that is the process of learning.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is about being real with ourselves. Math can be challenging, and everyone hits roadblocks sometimes, like getting stuck on a problem. It's okay if you're still working on some things; that's actually how mathematicians learn and grow, by sticking with it even when it's hard.

slides.text: What advice would you give to a student just starting the year? This question forces you to articulate what you have learned about learning math — which is more valuable than any single formula or procedure.
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine you're giving advice to yourself on the very first day of school this year. What would you tell yourself about learning math? Thinking about this helps you understand what you've really learned about *how* to learn math, which is a huge deal!

slides.prompt: Write your comprehensive mathematical reflection (2-3 paragraphs): (1) Describe your three biggest mathematical achievements. (2) Describe your biggest challenge and how you addressed it. (3) Share a specific breakthrough moment. (4) Explain your problem-solving style. (5) Write advice to a future student. (6) Set three specific, measurable math goals for next year. Add this reflection to your portfolio.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to write your whole math story! You'll look back at your work and achievements, talk about the toughest parts and how you tackled them, share that "aha!" moment, describe how you like to solve problems, and give that advice to a future student. Then, you'll set three clear goals for next year and add it all to your portfolio.

slides.text: Your mathematical story is one of growth, persistence, and discovery. The reflection you wrote today captures not just what you learned but who you became as a mathematical thinker. That identity — 'I am someone who can do hard math' — is the most important thing you take to middle school.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student articulate their mathematical growth, identify breakthrough moments, describe their problem-solving style, and set specific goals for continued development?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've just put together your whole math story! This reflection shows how much you've grown and learned, not just math facts, but about yourself as a thinker. Knowing you can tackle hard things is the biggest takeaway and will help you so much going forward.

parent_notes: Mathematical identity is as important as mathematical skill. How your child sees themselves in relation to math shapes their effort, persistence, and ultimately their achievement. If their reflection reveals anxiety or negative feelings about math, address them directly — many adults carry math anxiety from childhood that limits their lives unnecessarily. If their reflection reveals confidence and joy, celebrate that. Either way, the goals for next year give them agency over their mathematical future. Save this reflection — it is a valuable record of their learning journey.

title: Science Skills Review — The Scientific Method in Action
description: Students review the scientific method and all science skills developed during the year. They demonstrate mastery through a rapid-fire science challenge that requires observation, hypothesis formation, experimentation, and analysis in one lesson.
instructions:
1. Review the scientific method steps with examples from the year's experiments.
2. Discuss the science skills practiced: observation, measurement, data collection, graphing, analysis, conclusion.
3. Present a rapid-fire science challenge: a quick experiment that tests all skills in one session.
4. Observe the setup carefully and record detailed observations.
5. Form a hypothesis about the outcome.
6. Conduct the experiment following proper procedure.
7. Collect and organize data.
8. Analyze results and draw conclusions.
9. Identify sources of error.
10. Reflect on scientific thinking: How has the way you look at the world changed this year?
materials_needed: Quick experiment materials (e.g., paper airplane distance test, ice melting variables)

slides.heading: Science Skills Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this first slide is just giving us the big picture for today. We're going to be using everything we've learned about the scientific method, which is like a scientist's secret code for figuring things out, and putting it all into practice with a super quick experiment. Think of it as a science challenge where you get to show off all your awesome skills.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a quick, engaging experiment that can be completed in one session. Paper airplane distance testing (varying wing shape) or ice melting rate (varying insulation) work well. Have all materials and data sheets ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is like our shopping list for the science adventure. We've got our experiment stuff, which will be different depending on what we're testing, a data sheet to write down our findings, graph paper to make cool charts, a timer to keep track of our experiment, measuring tools like rulers or scales, and your science journal to jot down notes. Make sure you have all these things ready to go before we start.

slides.text: Today we put ALL your science skills to the test in one rapid-fire experiment. Observation, hypothesis, experimentation, data collection, analysis, and conclusion — all in one lesson. This is how real scientists work under pressure.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about getting your brain ready for action. We're going to use all the science skills we've practiced – observing things super closely, making smart guesses called hypotheses, doing the actual experiment, writing down what happens, and then figuring out what it all means. It's like a speed run of being a scientist, showing how you can do it all fast and accurately.

slides.text: Start by OBSERVING the materials carefully. What do you notice? What variables could you test? Form a HYPOTHESIS: 'If I change [variable], then [prediction] because [reasoning].'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be a super detective with the materials! Look at everything really carefully and think about what you notice, and what you could change to see if it makes a difference. Then, make your best guess, called a hypothesis, by saying "If I do *this*, then *that* will happen because *this*."

slides.text: Conduct your experiment with PRECISION. Follow your procedure exactly. Record data IMMEDIATELY — do not rely on memory. Take measurements carefully. Note anything unexpected.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you become the experimenter! You need to do exactly what you planned, super carefully, and write down your results right away so you don't forget anything. Make sure you measure things accurately and write down anything weird or surprising that happens.

slides.text: Analyze quickly but thoroughly. Create a graph. Calculate the mean if you have multiple trials. State your conclusion clearly: Was the hypothesis supported? What did you learn? What are the sources of error?
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to be a data wizard! Look at the numbers and information you collected, and make a graph to show it off visually. Figure out what your results mean, and see if they proved your hypothesis right or wrong. Also, think about any mistakes that might have happened during the experiment.

slides.prompt: Complete the rapid-fire science challenge: (1) Observe the materials and form a hypothesis (5 minutes). (2) Conduct the experiment with careful data collection (10 minutes). (3) Create a graph and calculate relevant statistics (5 minutes). (4) Write your conclusion (5 minutes). Show all steps clearly. Then write a final reflection: How has learning the scientific method changed the way you look at the everyday world?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the main event – our super-fast science challenge! You've got about 25 minutes to observe, guess, experiment, record, graph, and write down your conclusion. Afterwards, take a moment to think about how learning all these science steps has changed how you see the world around you every day.

slides.text: You just demonstrated every scientific skill you have learned this year — in one session. The scientific method is not just for science class. It is a way of thinking: observe carefully, form ideas, test them, analyze honestly, and learn from the results. Apply this thinking everywhere.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student apply the complete scientific method independently in a time-limited situation, collect and analyze data accurately, and reflect on how scientific thinking has changed their worldview?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you totally crushed it! You just used every single science skill you learned this year in one go, which is super impressive. Remember, the scientific method isn't just for experiments; it's a way to think about problems and learn new things in all parts of your life.

parent_notes: This rapid-fire challenge is energizing and confidence-building. The paper airplane experiment is especially fun: test different wing designs for distance, with multiple trials. The time pressure makes it exciting without being stressful. The final reflection question — how the scientific method has changed how you look at the world — is the most important part. If your child says they now question claims, look for evidence, or think more carefully about cause and effect, that is the most valuable outcome of the entire science curriculum.

title: Creative Self-Portrait — Expressing Identity Through Art
description: Students create a creative self-portrait that goes beyond physical appearance to represent their identity, interests, values, and dreams. They choose their medium and approach, applying year-long art skills to this deeply personal culminating work.
instructions:
1. Discuss self-portraits in art history: from Rembrandt to Frida Kahlo to contemporary artists.
2. Explain that today's self-portrait goes beyond appearance — it expresses who you ARE.
3. Brainstorm elements of identity to include: interests, values, favorite things, dreams, personality traits.
4. Explore different approaches: realistic, abstract, symbolic, collage, mixed media.
5. Choose a medium and approach.
6. Sketch the composition, incorporating identity elements.
7. Create the self-portrait, applying techniques learned throughout the year.
8. Write an artist's statement explaining the choices made and what they represent.
9. Share and discuss the completed portrait.
10. Add to the portfolio as a capstone personal artwork.

slides.heading: Creative Self-Portrait
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this first slide is like the big introduction to our project! It's called "Creative Self-Portrait," and the subtitle tells us the main idea: we're going to make art that shows not just what we look like, but who we really are inside. Think of it as making a picture that tells your story.

slides.setup_instructions: Display examples of creative self-portraits from various artists and styles. Set up a mirror for reference. Have a variety of art materials available for choice.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is about getting our supplies ready. We've got our art materials – that's anything you want to use to draw or paint with. The mirror is so you can see your face, but remember, we're going beyond just looks! Your sketchbook is for planning, the examples show cool ways artists have done this before, and the artist's statement template is where you'll write about your masterpiece.

slides.text: Artists have been making self-portraits for centuries — not just to show what they look like, but to express who they ARE. Frida Kahlo filled her self-portraits with symbols of her Mexican heritage and personal struggles. Your self-portrait should express your unique identity.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step is about understanding what a self-portrait can be. Artists for hundreds of years have made pictures of themselves, and it wasn't just about looking in a mirror. They used their art to show their feelings, their background, or what was important to them, like Frida Kahlo did with symbols. Your portrait should do the same – show your unique personality.

slides.text: Think beyond your face. What represents YOU? Your interests, your values, your dreams, your heritage, your favorite places, your personality? How can you incorporate these elements into a portrait that is unmistakably you?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's really dig into what makes you, YOU! This slide is asking you to think about more than just your hair color or your eyes. What do you love to do? What do you believe in? What are your biggest dreams? Think about your favorite things, your personality, and how you can show all of that in your picture.

slides.text: Choose your approach: Will your portrait be realistic, with symbolic elements in the background? Abstract, with colors and shapes representing your personality? A collage of images and words? Mixed media combining drawing with found objects? There is no wrong choice.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the artist and decide *how* you want to make your portrait. Will it look super realistic with maybe some special symbols added in? Or maybe more like an abstract painting where colors and shapes show your feelings? You could even make a collage with pictures and words. There's no single right way, so pick what feels cool to you.

slides.text: Apply the techniques you have learned all year. Strong composition, thoughtful color choices, attention to detail, and personal meaning — this portrait should represent your best artistic work AND your authentic self.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about using the awesome art skills you've learned this whole year. Remember how we worked on making cool drawings, picking colors that match a mood, and paying attention to details? This is your chance to show off all that practice in your self-portrait. It should look great *and* be super meaningful to you.

slides.prompt: Create your creative self-portrait: (1) Brainstorm identity elements to include. (2) Choose your medium and approach. (3) Sketch the composition. (4) Create the portrait using year-long art skills. (5) Write an artist's statement explaining what each element represents. This is your capstone personal artwork for the year.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to make some art! First, jot down all those ideas about yourself you brainstormed. Then, pick your art supplies and style. Next, sketch out how you want your portrait to look in your sketchbook. After that, create the actual portrait, using all those techniques we learned. Finally, use the template to write about why you chose certain things and what they mean. This is your big final project!

slides.text: Your creative self-portrait captures who you are at this moment in your life — your interests, your values, your dreams, and your artistic voice. It is both a work of art and a document of identity. Add it to your portfolio with pride.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student create a self-portrait that goes beyond physical appearance to express identity, apply appropriate artistic techniques, and write a reflective artist's statement?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! This self-portrait is like a snapshot of who you are right now – all your unique interests, your dreams, and your own artistic style are captured in this one piece. It's not just a drawing or painting; it's a piece of art that tells your story, and you should totally add it to your portfolio with pride.

parent_notes: The creative self-portrait is deeply personal and often becomes one of the most treasured artworks of the year. Let your child make all creative decisions — this is about THEIR identity expression. The artist's statement reveals how they see themselves, which can be illuminating for parents. Frame or display this portrait prominently. Consider taking a photograph of your child with their self-portrait as a keepsake. If they include elements that surprise you (interests or dreams you did not know about), use it as a starting point for conversation.

title: Time Management and Study Skills for Middle School
description: Students develop concrete time management and study skills they will need in middle school. They create personalized study systems, practice using a planner, learn about different learning styles, and develop strategies for managing homework across multiple subjects.
instructions:
1. Discuss why time management becomes more important in middle school: multiple teachers, more homework, extracurricular activities.
2. Introduce planner use: writing down assignments, due dates, and breaking large projects into smaller tasks.
3. Practice using a planner with a simulated week of middle school assignments.
4. Discuss learning styles: visual, auditory, kinesthetic, reading/writing — most people are a mix.
5. Help students identify their own learning preferences.
6. Introduce study strategies: flashcards, summarizing, teaching others, practice problems, graphic organizers.
7. Practice the Pomodoro technique: 25 minutes of focused work, 5-minute break.
8. Discuss managing distractions: phone, TV, noise.
9. Create a 'My Study System' personal reference guide.
10. Role-play: manage a busy week with multiple assignments due on different days.

slides.heading: Time Management and Study Skills
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey! This slide is like the title page for our adventure into getting ready for middle school. It's all about making sure you have a solid plan for managing your time and how you study, so middle school feels way less overwhelming and more like something you can totally conquer.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a sample planner. Create a simulated middle school assignment sheet with various due dates. Print the learning style inventory and study strategy reference cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide shows us all the cool tools we're going to use today. We've got a sample planner, which is like your personal secret weapon for keeping track of everything, and an assignment sheet that shows what a busy week might look like. We'll also use a learning style quiz, some strategy cards, a timer for our study sessions, and a template to build your own study system.

slides.text: In elementary school, your teacher managed your time. In middle school, YOU manage your time. You will have 5-7 different teachers, each assigning work independently. Without a system, things fall through the cracks. With a system, you stay on top of everything.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, in elementary school, your teacher was like the captain of the ship, guiding you. But in middle school, *you're* the captain! You'll have a bunch of different teachers, and each one will give you homework. This slide is just reminding us that if you don't have a plan, stuff can get missed, but having a system means you'll be in control and know exactly what's going on.

slides.text: PLANNERS are your lifeline. Write down EVERY assignment the moment it is given. Include the due date. For big projects, work backward: if a report is due Friday, research Monday, outline Tuesday, draft Wednesday, revise Thursday. Breaking big tasks into small steps makes them manageable.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important: your planner is your best friend for middle school! The big idea here is to write down *every single thing* you need to do the second you get it, especially the due date. For bigger projects, like a report, you'll learn to break it down into smaller steps and put those dates in your planner too, so it doesn't feel like too much all at once.

slides.text: The POMODORO TECHNIQUE: work with intense focus for 25 minutes, then take a 5-minute break. Repeat. This trains your brain to concentrate and prevents burnout. Most middle schoolers can finish homework in 2-3 Pomodoro sessions.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is a cool trick called the Pomodoro Technique. It means you'll work super hard and focused for 25 minutes, like a laser beam, and then you get a 5-minute break to totally chill. Doing this a few times can actually help you get all your homework done faster and without feeling totally wiped out.

slides.text: Know YOUR learning style. Do you learn best by seeing (visual), hearing (auditory), doing (kinesthetic), or reading (verbal)? Match your study strategies to your style: visual learners draw diagrams, auditory learners explain aloud, kinesthetic learners use hands-on models.
slides.mascot_explanation: Everyone learns differently, and this slide is about figuring out *your* best way. Do you remember things better when you see them (visual), hear them (auditory), do them (kinesthetic), or read them? Knowing this helps you pick the best study tricks, like drawing pictures if you're a visual learner or explaining things out loud if you learn by hearing.

slides.prompt: Create your personalized 'My Study System' guide: (1) Complete the learning style inventory and identify your preferences. (2) Practice filling in a planner with a simulated week of middle school assignments. (3) Choose 3 study strategies that match your learning style. (4) Practice one Pomodoro session (25 minutes of focused work). (5) Write your study rules: where you study, when you study, and how you manage distractions.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to build your own personalized "My Study System"! First, you'll take that quiz to see how you learn best. Then, you'll practice using the planner with that sample assignment sheet. After that, pick three study tricks that fit your learning style, try out one Pomodoro session, and finally, write down your own rules for where and when you study and how you'll avoid distractions.

slides.text: The students who thrive in middle school are not always the smartest — they are the most organized. Your Study System guide is a personalized roadmap for academic success. Use it from the very first day of middle school, and adjust it as you learn what works best for you.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student use a planner effectively, identify their learning style, apply appropriate study strategies, practice focused work sessions, and create a personalized study system?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your big finish! The slide is telling us that being organized is just as important as being smart for doing well in middle school. This "Study System" you're creating is like your personal map to success, so make sure you use it right from the start and keep tweaking it to make it perfect for you.

parent_notes: These practical skills are arguably the most important thing your child can learn before middle school. Buy a planner now and have them practice using it for the remaining weeks of the year. The learning style inventory helps both you and your child understand how they learn best. The Pomodoro technique is remarkably effective — consider using it yourself alongside your child. Discuss distraction management honestly; this may mean establishing phone-free study times. The 'My Study System' guide should be posted in their study area and reviewed at the start of middle school.

title: Letter to My Future Self — Capturing This Moment in Time
description: Students write a letter to their future selves to be opened in one year. They reflect on who they are now, what they have learned, what they hope for, and what advice they would give to their future middle school selves. This deeply personal writing exercise captures a moment in time.
instructions:
1. Discuss the tradition of writing letters to your future self.
2. Brainstorm topics to include: current interests, friends, worries, dreams, favorite things, daily life details.
3. Describe who you are RIGHT NOW: your personality, your strengths, your challenges.
4. Write about what you learned this year that surprised you.
5. Include specific details that will be meaningful later: favorite song, book, food, inside jokes.
6. Write advice to your future self about middle school.
7. Express hopes and dreams for the coming year.
8. Include a question for your future self to answer when they open the letter.
9. Seal the letter in an envelope with 'Open on [date one year from now].'
10. Give the sealed letter to a parent for safekeeping.
materials_needed: Wax seal or tape for sealing

slides.heading: Letter to My Future Self
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is the title page for our project: writing a letter to your future self! Think of it like creating a time capsule, but instead of objects, you're packing it with your thoughts, feelings, and experiences from right now. It's all about capturing this exact moment in time so you can look back on it later.

slides.setup_instructions: Provide nice stationery and a good pen — this is a special document. Have envelopes ready for sealing. Consider a wax seal or special sticker for the closure.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this activity, we need a few supplies to make our letter special. You'll need some nice stationery and a good pen because this letter is important. We also need an envelope to put it in, and some cool decorative elements like stickers or even a wax seal if you have one, to make it look extra fancy. Don't forget a date label for the envelope, which will tell your future self when to open it. Make sure you have a parent help you gather these things.

slides.text: A letter to your future self is a time capsule made of words. The person who opens this letter in one year will be different from you in ways you cannot predict. This letter preserves who you are right now — and that is a gift.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding *why* we're doing this. Writing a letter to yourself in the future is like sending a message through time! The person who reads this in a year will be you, but maybe a little different, and this letter is a way to show them exactly who you are right now. It’s a really cool gift to give your future self.

slides.text: Include specific, concrete details. Do not just write 'I like music.' Write 'Right now my favorite song is [title] by [artist] and I listen to it every morning.' Specific details are what make this letter priceless a year from now.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this slide is telling us to be super specific with our details. Instead of just saying "I like video games," you should write something like, "My favorite game right now is [game name] and I love playing it with my friends on Saturdays." Those kinds of specific details are what will make your letter feel like a real memory when you read it again.

slides.text: Be honest about your feelings. Write about your excitement for middle school AND your nervousness. Write about your proudest moments AND your biggest struggles. Your future self will appreciate the honesty.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is about being brave and honest. It's totally okay to feel excited about middle school, but it's also okay to feel a little nervous – your future self will understand! Write about the things you're really proud of accomplishing this year, but also the times you struggled, because that honesty is what will make the letter truly meaningful later.

slides.text: End with advice, hopes, and a question. Give your future self guidance based on what you know now. Share your biggest dream for the coming year. And ask a question that only your future self can answer: 'Did you make the basketball team? Did you find a best friend?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're looking at how to wrap up your letter. You'll want to give your future self some advice based on what you know now, maybe about handling middle school or staying true to yourself. Share your biggest dream for the next year, and then ask a question that only your future self will know the answer to, like "Did you learn to play that instrument?"

slides.prompt: Write your letter to your future self (at least one full page). Include: (1) A description of who you are right now. (2) Your current interests, favorites, and daily life details. (3) What you learned this year that surprised you. (4) Your proudest moment. (5) Advice for middle school. (6) Your biggest hope for the coming year. (7) A question for your future self. Seal the letter in an envelope dated one year from today.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is the main event – writing your letter! You need to fill at least a whole page with details about who you are right now, what you love, what you learned, and what you're proud of. Then, add your advice for middle school, your biggest hope, and that question for your future self. Once it's all written, seal it in the envelope and write "Open on [date one year from now]" on it. You've got 25 minutes to get this done!

slides.text: You have just created something that will be incredibly meaningful in one year. When you open this letter, you will meet the person you were today — and you will see how much you have grown. Give the sealed letter to your parent for safekeeping. It is a gift from present you to future you.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write a detailed, honest, personal letter that captures their current identity, includes specific details, offers advice, and expresses hopes for the future?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've created a special message for your future self that will be super meaningful when you open it next year. This letter is proof of who you are right now, and it will show you how much you've grown when you read it again. Now, give that sealed letter to your parent so they can keep it safe for you until the time is right.

parent_notes: This is often one of the most emotionally meaningful activities of the year. Give your child privacy while writing and do not read the letter unless they invite you to. Store it safely and set a calendar reminder for one year from now. When they open it as a middle schooler, the experience of meeting their past self is powerful and often emotional. Consider writing your own letter to your child to be opened alongside theirs. The combination of their letter to themselves and your letter to them creates a beautiful time capsule of this moment.

title: Math Celebration — Honoring a Year of Mathematical Growth
description: Students celebrate their mathematical journey with a festive showcase of their best work, mathematical games, and peer recognition. They share favorite problems, demonstrate skills, and honor the perseverance and growth they have achieved throughout the year.
instructions:
1. Set up a 'Math Gallery' displaying portfolio highlights, graphs, and best work.
2. Share mathematical autobiographies or favorite sections.
3. Play the student's favorite mathematical games from the year.
4. Each student demonstrates one math skill they are most proud of.
5. Share the most interesting or challenging problem solved this year.
6. Award certificates for specific mathematical achievements.
7. Play collaborative math challenges.
8. Review and celebrate middle school math goals.
9. Discuss: What will you miss about math class? What are you looking forward to?
10. Close with a final mathematical thought or puzzle to carry into summer.

slides.heading: Math Celebration
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover page for our big math party! It's called "Math Celebration" and it's all about looking back at everything awesome you've learned and accomplished in math this whole year. It's like a trophy for all your hard work!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a Math Gallery with portfolio highlights. Prepare certificates for various achievements. Have favorite math games ready. Create a festive atmosphere.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists all the cool stuff we need to make our Math Celebration happen. We've got your math portfolios with your best work, things to make our "Math Gallery" look amazing, fun math games we played, certificates to give out, and other party supplies. You'll want to grab your portfolio and maybe some cool markers or drawings to help decorate our gallery.

slides.text: Today we celebrate mathematics — not just the answers you got right, but the struggles you pushed through, the problems that made you think, and the moments when understanding clicked. Every mathematician's journey is worth celebrating.
slides.mascot_explanation: This instruction tells us the main idea for today: we're celebrating math! It's not just about getting the right answers, but about how you tackled tricky problems, kept trying even when it was tough, and those "aha!" moments when something finally made sense. Your math journey is super important and worth celebrating!

slides.text: Walk through the Math Gallery and appreciate your own work. Remember when fractions seemed impossible? Look at what you can do now. Remember your first equation? Now you solve multi-step equations with variables on both sides.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about you checking out the "Math Gallery" we're going to set up. It's a chance to look at your own amazing work from the year and really see how much you've improved. Think about how hard some of those problems used to be, and then look at what you can do now – that's awesome progress!

slides.text: Demonstrate the skill you are most proud of. It might be solving equations, creating graphs, calculating probability, or something else entirely. Show it off — you earned this.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your moment to shine! You get to pick one math skill you're really proud of and show everyone how well you can do it. Maybe it's solving equations super fast, making cool graphs, or figuring out chances with probability – whatever it is, you've totally earned the right to show it off!

slides.text: Here is a puzzle to carry into summer: I am thinking of a number. If you double it and add 10, you get 36. What is my number? (When you figure it out, you have solved an equation — which proves you are an algebraic thinker.)
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a fun little brain teaser to take with you for the summer. It's a number puzzle that actually uses algebra, which you've learned! Think about what number, when you double it and add 10, gives you 36. Solving it shows you're already thinking like a math whiz!

slides.prompt: Participate in the math celebration: (1) Display your best mathematical work in the gallery. (2) Demonstrate one skill you are most proud of. (3) Share the most interesting problem you solved this year. (4) Play mathematical games with enthusiasm. (5) Solve the final puzzle. (6) Write one sentence completing this prompt: 'The most important thing I learned about math this year is...'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the main event where we put everything together! You'll get to show off your best math work in the gallery, demonstrate that skill you're proud of, share a challenge problem, play some games, and solve that summer puzzle. Plus, you'll write one sentence about the coolest math thing you learned this year.

slides.text: Mathematics is a lifelong journey of discovery. This year you traveled farther than you might realize. Whether you love math or are still learning to appreciate it, you have grown enormously. Carry that growth — and a little mathematical curiosity — into every year that follows.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student display mathematical work proudly, demonstrate a mastered skill, articulate what they learned about math this year, and approach mathematical challenges with confidence?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're wrapping up our math year, and this slide is a reminder that math is a journey that never really ends. You've grown so much this year, whether you loved every minute or found it a bit challenging sometimes. Take that growth and that curiosity with you as you keep learning new things!

parent_notes: End the math year on a high note. Celebrate specific achievements: 'Remember when you could not multiply fractions? Now look at you!' The certificates should recognize different kinds of mathematical excellence: Most Persistent, Most Creative Problem-Solver, Greatest Growth, Best Mathematical Communicator. If math has been a struggle for your child, emphasize growth over achievement — every step forward matters. The puzzle at the end (the answer is 13) is a playful reminder that they are algebraic thinkers now. Keep the math portfolio alongside the other portfolios.

title: What History Teaches Us — Lessons for the Future
description: Students reflect on the overarching lessons of their year of historical study, identifying patterns that repeat across eras and applying historical wisdom to contemporary challenges. They create a personal 'Lessons from History' document as a capstone reflection.
instructions:
1. Review all major historical periods studied this year.
2. Identify patterns that repeat across eras: rise and fall of civilizations, innovation driving change, the power of ideas, the consequences of injustice.
3. Discuss George Santayana's quote: 'Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.'
4. Examine a current event through a historical lens: What past events does it parallel?
5. Discuss what history teaches about human nature: ambition, creativity, compassion, conflict.
6. Students identify the three most important lessons from their year of history study.
7. For each lesson, provide a historical example and a modern application.
8. Write a 'Lessons from History' essay or create an infographic.
9. Discuss how historical thinking helps in daily decision-making.
10. Close with: What is one thing you will always remember from studying history this year?

slides.heading: What History Teaches Us
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big project at the end of the year. It's telling us that by looking back at everything we've studied in history, we can learn some really important stuff that will help us figure out what might happen in the future and how we can make things better.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather history notes from the year. Have the completed timeline visible for reference. Select 1-2 current events that parallel historical events studied.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is like our supply list for the project. We'll need our old history notes to jog our memory, the timeline we made to see how things connect, some articles about what's happening in the world right now, paper and colored pencils for writing or drawing, and maybe a special template if we decide to make an infographic. Make sure you gather all these things so you're ready to go!

slides.text: You have traveled through thousands of years of human history this year. Now step back and ask: What does it all add up to? What patterns repeat? What lessons should we carry forward?
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like hitting the pause button on our history journey. We've covered so much ground, from ancient times to more recent events, and now it's time to think about the big picture. What are the main takeaways? What kind of stories or patterns keep showing up again and again throughout history?

slides.text: History reveals patterns: civilizations rise when they innovate and cooperate; they decline when they stop adapting or become divided. Ideas — democracy, human rights, scientific thinking — are more powerful than armies. Injustice always eventually faces resistance.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this slide is pointing out some of those repeating patterns. It explains that civilizations often grow when people invent new things and work together, but they can fall apart if they stop changing or start fighting amongst themselves. It also highlights that big ideas can be way more powerful than any army, and that unfairness usually causes trouble down the road.

slides.text: Apply historical thinking to today. Climate change parallels past environmental collapses. Political polarization echoes historical divisions. Technological revolution mirrors the Industrial Revolution. History does not predict the future, but it illuminates the present.
slides.mascot_explanation: Think of this slide as putting on special glasses that let you see history in today's news. It's saying that when we look at current problems, like climate change or people disagreeing a lot, we can often find similar situations that happened way back when. History doesn't tell us exactly what's going to happen, but it sure does help us understand what's going on right now.

slides.text: The most personal lesson from history is this: ordinary people shape the future. Every movement began with individuals who decided to act. You are one of those individuals. What will your impact be?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really cool part that makes history personal. It's telling us that throughout history, it wasn't just kings or famous leaders who made big changes – it was regular people who decided to speak up or take action. This slide is reminding you that you have the power to make a difference in the world too, and it’s asking you to think about how you might do that.

slides.prompt: Create your 'Lessons from History' document: Identify three major lessons from your year of historical study. For each lesson: (1) State the lesson. (2) Provide a historical example. (3) Explain how it applies to the modern world. (4) Describe how it might guide your own decisions. Choose format: essay, infographic, or illustrated page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be creative and show what you've learned! You need to pick out three big lessons from all the history we studied this year. For each lesson, write down what it is, give a real example from history, explain how it's still relevant today, and then think about how that lesson could help you make good choices in your own life. You can write it out like an essay or make a cool infographic or drawing.

slides.text: History is not just the past — it is the lens through which we understand the present and shape the future. The knowledge you have built this year makes you a more informed citizen, a more thoughtful person, and a more effective agent of change. Remember these lessons.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify repeating historical patterns, apply historical lessons to contemporary events, create a 'Lessons from History' document, and articulate how historical thinking guides personal decision-making?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the final wrap-up slide, and it’s a great reminder of why history matters. It’s saying that learning about the past isn’t just about memorizing dates; it’s about gaining wisdom that helps us understand today and build a better tomorrow. You’ve learned so much this year, and that knowledge makes you a more capable person who can actually help make the world a better place.

parent_notes: This capstone history lesson asks for genuine intellectual synthesis. Discuss the big patterns with your child — it is a fascinating conversation for the whole family. The connection between historical events and current news makes the subject feel alive and relevant. The personal application ('How might this guide your decisions?') is the most important element. If your child identifies with historical change-makers, encourage that identification — believing they can make a difference is the first step toward actually doing so.

title: Science Year in Review — Celebrating Scientific Curiosity
description: Students review the full year of scientific study, from physical science through life science, earth science, and the human body. They identify their favorite experiments, biggest discoveries, and continuing questions, and celebrate the scientific mindset they have developed.
instructions:
1. Review all science topics from the year: physical science, life science, earth science, human body systems.
2. Identify the most memorable experiment from each unit.
3. Discuss which scientific concepts changed how you see the everyday world.
4. Share the most surprising thing learned in science this year.
5. Create a 'Year in Science' visual summary or mind map.
6. Identify three questions that science class inspired but did not answer.
7. Discuss how to continue scientific exploration over the summer.
8. Review the nature journal as evidence of developing observation skills.
9. Write a science reflection: How has learning science changed the way you think?
10. Close with a 'I am a scientist because...' statement.
materials_needed: Science journal and notes from the year

slides.heading: Science Year in Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this first slide is just the title page for our big science review. It's like the cover of a cool book that tells us we're going to look back at everything awesome we learned in science this whole year and celebrate how curious we've been.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all science work from the year. Prepare a large sheet of paper for the mind map. Have the nature journal and science fair materials accessible.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us all the stuff we need to get ready for our big review project. We've got our science notes from the year, some big paper and markers to make a cool poster, photos from our science fair, our nature journal where we drew and wrote about what we saw, and some plain paper for writing. Go grab all these things so we're ready to go!

slides.text: This year you explored the physical world, the living world, the earth, and your own body. You learned to observe like a scientist, hypothesize like a scientist, experiment like a scientist, and think like a scientist. That is remarkable.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is reminding us of all the amazing science topics we covered this year, from how things move and energy works (physical science) to plants, animals, and how they live (life science), to weather and rocks (earth science), and even how our own bodies work. It's also pointing out that we've been practicing being real scientists by observing, guessing, testing, and thinking critically.

slides.text: Which experiment do you remember most vividly? The one that surprised you? The one that did not work as expected? The one that made you say 'Wow'? Those moments of wonder are the heart of science.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, think back to all the experiments we did. Which one really sticks out in your mind? Maybe it was super surprising, or maybe it totally flopped and taught us something important even though it didn't "work" the way we expected. Those "aha!" or "oops!" moments are what science is all about.
